cip.render.util3d

Class Vector3f

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.util3d.Vector3f

  • public class Vector3f
extends java.lang.Object
    A class representing a vector in 3D of single precision (the components are represented by float values), hence the name Vector3f.

    This class implements the basic functionality for a 3D vector required for rendering and 3D graphics use. This class is patterned after and most code adapted from the CUnitV3f class of the JOEY toolkit written and distributed by Crisis in Perspective, Inc.

    Since:
    1.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • Vector3f

        public Vector3f()
        Creates a new instance of Vector3f. This uses the default initialization of the fields setting the vector to 0,0,0.

      • Vector3f

        public Vector3f(float i,
                float j,
                float k)
        Creates a new instance of Vector3f with the I, J, and K components set as specified. No normalization is performed, the values are set exactly as specified.
        Parameters:
        i - The I component of the vector.
        j - The J component of the vector.
        k - The K component of the vector.

      • Vector3f

        public Vector3f(Vector3f v)
        Creates a new instance of Vector3f set equal to another vector.
        Parameters:
        v - The vector to make this new vector equal to.

      • Vector3f

        public Vector3f(Point3f ptOrg,
                Point3f ptThru)
        Creates a new instance of Vector3f initialized to be a vector from ptOrg to ptThru. This length of this vector is equal to the distance from ptOrg to ptThru. The vector should be normalized if you need a direction vector.
        Parameters:
        ptOrg - The start of the vector.
        ptThru - The end of the vector.

    • Method Detail

      • setValue

        public Vector3f setValue(float i,
                         float j,
                         float k)
        Sets the I, J, and K components as specified. No normalization is performed, the values are set exactly as specified.
        Parameters:
        i - The I component of the vector.
        j - The J component of the vector.
        k - The K component of the vector.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector with the value set as specified.

      • setValue

        public Vector3f setValue(Point3f ptOrg,
                         Point3f ptThru)
        Sets the value of the vector to be a vector from ptOrg to ptThru. This length of this vector is equal to the distance from ptOrg to ptThru. You should normalized this vector if you need a direction vector.
        Parameters:
        ptOrg - The start of the vector.
        ptThru - The end of the vector.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector with the value set as specified.

      • setValue

        public Vector3f setValue(Vector3f v)
        Sets the value of this vector (each of the components) to be equal to some other vector, v.
        Parameters:
        v - The vector to make this vector equal to. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector with its components set equal to vector v.

      • reverse

        public Vector3f reverse()
        Reverse the direction of this vector. This is the same as scaling the vector by -1.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector after it has been reversed.

        Returns:

        Returns:

      • subtract

        public Vector3f subtract(Vector3f v)
        Subtracts a vector, v, from this vector.
        Parameters:
        v - The vector to be subtracted from this vector. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector after vector v has been subtracted.

      • cross

        public Vector3f cross(Vector3f v)
        Cross this vector with another vector, v. The cross product produces a vector perpendicular to the 2 vectors crossed. Specifically, the X axis crossed with the Y axis will produce the Z axis, while the cross of the Y axis with the X axis will produce the -Z axis. NOTE: i cross j = k; j cross k = i; and k cross i = j regardless of the handedness of the coordinate system being used.
        Parameters:
        v - The vector to be crossed with this vector. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector after vector v has been subtracted.

      • setToReflection

        public Vector3f setToReflection(Vector3f vNormal,
                                Vector3f vFrom)
                         throws ZeroLengthVectorException
        Sets this vector to the the reflection of the vFrom vector around the surface normal, vNormal. NOTE: it does not matter which side of the surface is the inside or the outside (i.e. the dot product between the normal and the vector from the surface may be either positive or negative.

        This computation is performed as described in Illumination and Color in Computer Generated Imagery by Roy Hall, Appendix III.1 Geometry utilities.

        Although the math should produce a normalized vector if the input vectors are normalized, the reflection vector is re-normalized after computation to minimize the buildup of round off errors.

        Parameters:
        vNormal - The surface normal. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        vFrom - The vector from the surface to be reflected about the normal. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector set to the reflection of the vFrom vector around the surface normal, vNormal.
        Throws:
        ZeroLengthVectorException

      • setToRefraction

        public boolean setToRefraction(Vector3f vNormal,
                               Vector3f vFrom,
                               float fN_in,
                               float fN_out)
        Sets this vector to the the refraction of the vFrom vector at the surface given by the normal vNormal. NOTE: it does not matter which side of the surface is the inside or the outside (i.e. the dot product between the normal and the vector from the surface may be either positive or negative.

        This computation is performed as described in Illumination and Color in Computer Generated Imagery by Roy Hall, Appendix III.1 Geometry utilities.

        Parameters:
        vNormal - The surface normal. The value of this vector is unchanged.
        vFrom - The vector from the surface for which we want the refraction (by convention, all vectors are from the surface when the computations are made). The value of this vector is unchanged.
        fN_in - The index of refraction of the material the vFrom vector is traveling through.
        fN_out - The index of refraction of the material the refracted vector will be traveling through.
        Returns:
        Returns false if there is no refracted vector (total internal reflection occurs), and true if a refracted vector was computed. If false is returned, the value of this vector is arbitrary and it should be considered uninitialized.

      • setToHt

        public boolean setToHt(Vector3f vL,
                       Vector3f vT,
                       float ni,
                       float nt)
        Compute the microfacet surface normal, Ht, that would be required to refract light from the L direction in the T direction.
        Parameters:
        vL - The light vector, L
        vT - The transmitted direction, T
        ni - The index of refraction for L
        nt - The index of refraction for T
        Returns:
        Returns true if Ht was computed amd false if a valid Ht does not exist for this geometry

      • getLength

        public float getLength()
        Get the length of this vector.
        Returns:
        Returns the length of this vector. The length is always >= 0.

      • normalize

        public Vector3f normalize()
                   throws ZeroLengthVectorException
        Normalize this vector - in other words, scale the vector so its length is equal to 1 and it can be used as a direction vector.
        Returns:
        This vector is returned after normalization.
        Throws:
        ZeroLengthVectorException - The exception is thrown when the length of the vector is eoo close to zero that normalizing the vector returns a meaningless result.

      • scale

        public Vector3f scale(float fScale)
        Scale a vector - multiply each of its components by a scaling factor.
        Parameters:
        fScale - The scaling factor.
        Returns:
        Returns this vector after it has been scaled.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Vector3f v)
        Tests another vector, v, for equality with this vector.
        Parameters:
        v - The vector to be tested. This vector is unchanged.
        Returns:
        Returns true if v is equal to this vector (identical in all components), and false otherwise.
